title: Synthetic Recap
body:
WASHINGTON — On a night defined by grit and defensive struggle, one man authored a performance for the ages. Grant Hill, with a Herculean effort, single-handedly willed the Detroit Pistons to an 85-79 victory over the Washington Bullets, pouring in a career-high and eye-popping 44 points.

In an era where final scores rarely dipped below 100, this contest was a throwback bruiser. Neither team could find an offensive rhythm, with the game hanging in the balance deep into the fourth quarter. But amidst the clanging iron and tangled defenses, Hill was a portrait of sublime efficiency and explosive force. He was the piston in the Pistons' engine, driving, cutting, and elevating over every defender the Bullets threw at him.

His 44 points were not just a number; they were a narrative. With his teammates struggling to convert, Hill became the sole focal point, carrying the offensive load on his shoulders. Each basket was a hammer blow to Washington's resolve, each drive to the rim a statement of individual brilliance. The Bullets, led by Chris Webber's 20 points and 10 rebounds, simply had no answer.

While the final margin was six points, this was not a team victory won by committee. This was a testament to one player's transcendent talent on a night when nothing else was working. In a grinding, defensive battle, Grant Hill didn't just win the game; he dominated it, securing a historic night that would be etched into the franchise's legacy.
